title: 108_s2790
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Bisti PRLA Dispute Resolution Act" and involves the withdrawal of coal preference right lease applications. The Bisti PRLA Dispute Resolution Act involves the withdrawal of coal preference right lease applications. If any of the specified applications are withdrawn, the Secretary of the Interior will issue a certificate of bidding rights to the holders, relinquishing all associated rights without further adjudication. The Bisti PRLA Dispute Resolution Act involves the withdrawal of coal preference right lease applications. If any applications are withdrawn, the Secretary will issue a certificate of bidding rights to the holders, relinquishing all associated rights without further adjudication. SEC. 3. METHOD FOR DETERMINING FAIR MARKET VALUE. The section applies to the issuance of a certificate of bidding rights for coal reserves. The fair market value of withdrawn coal preference right lease applications will be determined by a panel established by the Secretary. The Secretary will appoint a panel to determine the fair market value of withdrawn coal preference right lease applications. The panel may supplement information as needed and must submit their determination to the Secretary within 75 days. SEC. 4. ISSUANCE OF PATENTS TO RELINQUISHED PREFERENCE RIGHT LEASE APPLICATIONS.

Within 120 days of withdrawing a coal preference right lease application, the Secretary must issue patents to the Navajo Nation for the land, including the mineral estate, to satisfy their land selection rights under the Navajo-Hopi Land Settlement Act. This aims to facilitate land consolidation and mineral development in northwest New Mexico. Additionally, a certificate of bidding rights will be issued based on the fair market value determined. Enforcement of these duties is considered nondiscretionary and can be enforced through a mandamus proceeding.

SEC. 5. USE OF EXCHANGE BIDDING RIGHTS. The certificate of bidding rights issued under section 4(a)(2) allows for transferability and can be used as a credit against payments to the Secretary for Federal coal leases. The certificate of bidding rights issued under section 4(a)(2) can be used as a monetary credit against a payment obligation under a Federal coal lease. The holder can apply the bidding rights against 50% of the amount payable under the lease and must pay the remaining 50% in cash or cash equivalent. Any payment made using the certificate of bidding rights shall be treated as money received under the Mineral Leasing Act and credited accordingly by the Secretary. The amount paid through a crediting of the bidding rights involved shall be distributed to the State where the lease is located and treated as a redistribution under the Mineral Leasing Act. 50 percent of this amount will be subject to redistribution to the Reclamation and Miscellaneous Receipts accounts in the Treasury.
